comment._content: The Irish Times archive mentions a bacon-curers strike in 1890 in Limerick, and a Waterford bacon trade dispute in 1896 though ... A quick scan of the articles seems to show that, despite the time gap, the disputes seem to be linked, and involved Shaws and Dennys...

comment._content: Not a very nice thing to say about those nice policemen!  I note that the police are all in step and some are showing very significant beards!  Shock horror, wouldn't be allowed today!

comment._content:
In those far-off days, law enforcement officers displayed their seniority of service by the amount of facial hair. Generally recruits were clean-shaven, then came a moustache, followed by a beard. Unknown if this required offficlal sanction. Same applied all over. Here's an example from Caithness-shire constabulary in North of Scotland:

comment.author: 63844591@N04
comment._content: Pig buyers in Waterford, based around the Ballybricken area,  traditionally had a monopoly on buying from farmers and selling to the bacon factories. Strike happened because the factories started to buy direct from farmers
